title: 107_hr2383
content: Increased exclusion and modifications for qualified small business stock are outlined in Section 1. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%. Amendments include reducing the holding period from 5 years to 3 years and allowing the exclusion to be available to corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from certain small business stock from 50% to 100%, reducing the holding period from 5 years to 3 years. The exclusion is now available to corporations, with specific provisions regarding stock held among members of controlled groups. Additionally, the minimum tax preference is repealed. Section 53(d)(1)(B)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to remove references to certain sections. Section 1202(d) is also amended to increase the asset limitation for qualified small businesses from $50,000,000 to $300,000,000, with an inflation adjustment provision for stock issued after 2002. Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to repeal the per-issuer limitation and make other modifications, including extending the working capital period from 2 to 5 years. The Internal Revenue Code Section 1202 is amended to allow exceptions from redemption rules for stock purchases with a business purpose. The definition of qualified trade or business is also revised. The amendments made by this section apply to stock issued after the date of enactment of this Act, with special rules for stock issued after August 10, 1993. SEC. 2 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal the minimum tax preference for exclusion for incentive stock options. This amendment applies to options exercised in calendar years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
